The Act titled "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" defines terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area, Program, and Secretary. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE PROGRAM. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is established within the Department of the Interior with goals to decrease fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems. The Secretary will develop projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality and prevent fish from entering water supply systems by implementing projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Eligible projects include developing fish screens, fish passage devices, and other related features agreed upon by non-Federal interests, relevant Federal and tribal agencies, and affected States. Additionally, States will conduct inventories to determine the need and priority for such projects. The Secretary will prioritize projects costing less than $5,000,000 based on inventories conducted by States to assess the need for fish mitigation projects in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. SEC. 4. PARTICIPATION IN THE PROGRAM. Non-Federal participation is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Federal projects on U.S. land are nonreimbursable.

SEC. 5. EVALUATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF PROJECTS. Evaluation and prioritization of projects under the Program is based on benefits to native fish species, water diversion size, funding availability, cost effectiveness, and potential biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements are also outlined. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, as well as approval from all relevant Federal and non-Federal entities. The Secretary will consult with various agencies and utilize available data to determine project eligibility. The non-Federal share of the cost for projects under the Program on non-Federal land is 35 percent. Non-Federal participants must provide necessary land and resources for the project, which will be credited towards the project's value. Non-Federal participants in projects on non-Federal land must cover 35% of the costs and provide land and resources. Costs for projects on Federal land are the responsibility of the Federal Government. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive Federal funds from any other source for the same purpose. SEC. 9. REPORT. SEC. 9. REPORT. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress after the third fiscal year, detailing completed projects, projects to be completed in future fiscal years, and recommended Program changes. Authorized funding of $25,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2001-2005 under this Act. Limitations include not more than 25% of funds for projects in a single state, with a waiver option if the state cannot utilize the full amount. Administrative expenses capped at 6%. Administrative expenses capped at 6% of funds authorized for carrying out this Act.
